eLCJTl--iBCk3k0LCSN_tg.text: Ciao Bella is one of the places I go to at least once a month (I even have it take away sometimes).  I think they have a very good and simple Italian food, nice parmigiano cheese and olives to get you starting. And I like their veals steaks they are just good to have.  I'm a fan ... Though I think their service sucks!

2SmaD6-ksPzGFzBb4jLuaw.text: The only thing better than stuffing tasty pasta down your gullet is doing it whilst listening to a man who moonlights as a Liberace impersonator do a version of Mariah Carey's 'Hero.'I'll take a moment to let you digest that statement..........It was cold out when we rounded the corner onto Lamb's Conduit Street and saw Ciao Bella glowing (literally) like a beacon of warmth and tastiness. The portions are huge and so spot-hitting you'd be willing to pay just about anything. Luckily the place is also reasonably priced so there's no fear of losing an arm or a leg when the check comes. I'd wager that the only medical procedure you might require is arterial bypass; these guys aren't stingy with the cheese.It's just a fun family spot with hearty fare. It'll go in my little black book for sure.

EdvvnO9gUy8pCQgGJ1vYhQ.text: The plan was to meet at the pub next door, then pop over to Ciao Bella for a low-key bite. And what an experience! There's seldom a vibe that can be matched by a bustling cheery Italian restaurant  this place was absolutely heaving, filled with happy, chatting people and fuelled by the boisterous waiters rushing about despatching plates to tables with a certain brash informality.The piano player was over on one side of the room, standing behind his upright piano (no room for anything else in here!), and making his way between lounge standards and old songs that everyone knows  though you could scarcely hear him over the din.I wouldn't give this place any awards for the food, that's for sure. But you get the feeling it's more designed as the Cheap & Cheerful student haunt or casual meal spot  and who complains about a starter being a plate of microscopic previously frozen prawns in sauce when it's only cost you £6.50, and you've got access to bottles of house red wine for £13.50. In Bloomsbury!Spaghetti Carbonara is a bit like the Sweet & Sour Pork equivalent of Chinese food  it's probably not particularly authentic or subtle, but you can get it almost everywhere, and I really like it: so that's my Italian yardstick. And on this occasion it was different. Not bad at all, but certainly not what I was expecting. But again  for £8, and accompanied by wine, good vibe, and excellent conversation, I'd go back in & have it tomorrow!The piano player belts out a chorus of Old MacDonald's Farm from the piano, totally unnoticed by anyone. We applaud at the end: he looks up with surprise that anyone's paid any attention and smiles at us, where many others in the room stop talking to see what the fuss was about, and several suddenly realise there's a piano there. The restaurant was full when we arrived, and people are still arriving as we leave.How have I not heard of this place before?

egj9KX8qZPyVoOp1xZVIHA.text: Food 4/10Atmosphere 5/10Service 2/10Food:I did my regular mental IRS (Italian Restaurant Shuffle) of 'oohhh, I really fancy a nice comforting carbonara, but shouldn't I try something different as I'm out?' and the coin fell this time on carboara.  I wish it hadn't.  This was the blandest I've ever tried.  Very little meat, and NO SALT!  Hot cream and spaghetti is not tasty!  One of my friends had shellfish, so I didn't try hers (shellfish spends all its life sifting through the poo of other sea creatures and eating it - nuff said) but she said it was ok, albeit also lacking in salt.  Friend #3 had to stop eating her pasta halfway through because no amount of extra seasoning would bring it to life.  Maybe they ran out of salt, or a safety conscious slug was cooking that night (geddit?), in which case it's a great pity, because it means that I cannot join in with the other reviewers who praise the food here.The big dark green olives on the table were hard and yucky.  There was a hard little lump of parmesan next to them, the size of a newborn's fist.  Why?  None of us wanted to nibble on a large dry piece of neat parmesan, and the waiter brought his own to us when he came to us, grater in hand.  As the room heated up and our cross-table conversation flowed, I keep geting strong wafts of open-air cheese.  Atmosphere:Absolutely jam-packed like sardines.  I sat facing a huge wall length mirror (as did half of the customers) which was very disconcerting.  Although I do have a pleasant face, I don't really need to look at it all the way through a meal.  It also highlighted how small the basement seating area was, because resorting to a wall-sized mirror is a pretty cheap and desperate conjouring trick.Yucky laminated menu which included lurid colour photos of the desserts. Not cool.Service:This was the real killer.  We arrived and were brusquely directed downstairs, and as we walked down, the oddly toneless order  'you must leave by 8pm' (giving us 40 minutes) was called down to us.  No questioning whether that would be ok, or stating it politely.  Luckily, it was ok!On arrival downstairs, a very pissed off looking waiter greeted us with a frown and a 'there is no space'.  I replied that we had been told we could come down, as long as we left by 8pm.  He sighed, said 'ok then', and pointed to a table.  We were left to squeeze past the diners on the very close table behind ours, and jam our coats on the back of our chairs.  Already fuming, I was tempted to leave.  Wine calmed me down, but the surly, frankly shit service continued throughout the meal.  When he was cheesing my plate up, the same pissed-off waiter barely kissed my food with a light powdering of the good stuff before huffily, distractedly moving as if to go.  When I politely said that I'd like a little more, he sighed loudly before tetchily scratching a bit more on and leaving, again too rapidly.Don't get me started on how long it took to get the dessert menu or bill.  No further attention was paid to us, and I had to resort to waving, which made me feel very rude.A different, very nice old waiter came to us at the end when we needed change, and he was charming.Reading the other reviews here, I feel even more cheated.  Perhaps this was just an unusually lousy evening, with angry young staff  frustrated by the lateness of their much needed salt delivery.

fbozUeBB2et9l0bbwZkp2g.text: Let's be honest -- on the yardstick of tacky Italian restaurant names, Ciao Bella is right up there with "The great Impasta" and "Papa Razzi." But I quickly shut my cheeky mouth (or rather, stuffed it) when some of the most drool-worthy, fork spinning, bread dipping lasagna and aubergine parmigiana appeared steaming on our table.I am perhaps the only person in the world that isn't much of an Italian food fan. Their wine is another story, clearly. However the incredible pasta at Ciao Bella could make a believer our of Mr. Atkins himself.A 1/2 bottle of wine, a large house salad and two entrees for £27? It's amore!

NFn0NnIHDQrbrbRUx9C_Jw.text: This restaurant is excellent for the buzz as it is always busy with a great volume of people chatting and a pianist come singer in the corner upping the volume levels even more.The food is good value but not served with any panache - large portion dumped in front of you - more greasy spoon appearance than restaurantMy friend had the veal and reported it excellent whereas I had the Insalata Nicoise which was appalling.  The tiramisu for desert was home made and a massive portion flooded in an Amaretto sauce and heavily dusted with chocolate powder. I doubt if I will bother with this one again in the near future.

id_lsM1-b9uM9Rf759JhEw.text: On my first visit to Ciao Bella I treated it as a Pizzeria - how wrong I was. The food is excellent - Roasted rack of lamb with chestnuts is beautiful. The service and decor are ok, and there's a pianist some nights too.The atmosphere is pretty good most nights because you can generally count on there being a birthday party somewhere in the restaurant.I'm very jealous of a friend who can call this his local restaurant - at one point he was in every week so the manager knew his name!

Z5Ga12pbHD5nn6gcDtLGCg.text: Do not let the name put you off,Ciao Bella is a great restaurant offering well above average plates of delicious food - portions are HUGE.Puts alot of italian ' chain' restaurants to shame.The only thing is it gets so loud you cannot hear anything as it is so busy - full to bursting with customers every night,and some of the staff are very brusque in manner....but the food and good prices make up for this.Pasta is great as is the Veal escalope milanese.

MDk4MBY04RsSakpILtbUOg.text: Lovely italian restaurant, my first 'local' in London. Always busy, slightly frantic staff but a really warm atmosphere. They're generous with the food (classic italian) and it's really well priced for London. Even though it gets busy towards the end of the week, they usually try to fit you in and if you're faced with an hours wait there's always The Lamb pub next door, The Rugby Tavern or The Perseverance down the road. It's worth the wait.

9Y7HAUG3yOMmItn4dAGYZQ.text: Ciao Bella's food is the saving grace. I think their spaghetti and meatballs are amongst the best I've had in London. I've never bothered to ask about it, but the little chunks of Parmesan to nibble on while you wait (is it parm? could be summat else) are divine.The service is brusque, so if you're going with people who tend to be indecisive, prepare to be scowled at and have the staff walk off. They do this regardless of if the place is packed or just opened and you're the only table. That said, if you're in a rush for something and can get a table, it's pretty easy to be in and out of here with a good meal in your belly. I think there's a small discount for takeaway dining if you're local, but I wouldn't recommend it. I once called in an order, was told 20 minutes, and then stood there like a plank waiting for another 30 minutes. Had I not already paid, I would've left. I'd recommend a reservation for nighttime dining. But as a good place for a date? Come on, y'all. It'd be like taking a date to your nana's kitchen.

ep1GXNSXXHD3LxQQcLwePw.text: My favorite Italian restaurant. I love the food here  it's freshly made, right out of the oven and delicious. The place is a must for every pizza and pasta lover. Also, the service is on a high level so you won't get unattended for long.

i1_nwqmTvMNPm9S6KWgM2w.text: This place was freaking packed! and it is jam packed like a bunch of sardines downstairs. TBx7QHMVKHMgjn8IQn2CTQ.text: Was recommended this place. Called early in the day for a reservation that night. Apparently Friday's and Saturday's get quite busy. The woman was very accommodating and booked the two of us for 7:30. We finally get there promptly and ask for our table. One of the owners scours the book looking for my name, thinking that I'm trying to pull one over on him. Apparently, his Mama took the reservation, but forgot to put it on the books. Just make sure to make a reservation earlier in the week. Around 8pm, it starts to get really busy and queues up. Especially if there are a couple big parties.

m9scfKwsB8DIyYIvMborbg.text: Nice cosy italian restaurant. I like coming here with friends. They always serve our order quickly and I've never gone there and not have a table even without booking. So I recommend if you're fan of pizza and pasta.

Y7Vb9hfOJHLJudijVcKvzQ.text: The food at Ciao Bella is good...not great...but their dishes are big and filling, so it's nice to go with a group. There are lots of cute boutiques around the area too, which are worth checking out.

P0KMXkbTgxS9Z_ZB1S3t4w.text: As an American, I don't know a lot of good neighborhood spots in London. Too often I'm in a tourist place of some kind.  After consulting Yelp, I found this place near where I was staying, but some reviews said reservations are needed.  I had no car, it was about 20 minutes by foot, and it was about to rain. But the alternatives were not great.  When I got there, a waitress said it was full, no chance, outta here.  Before I could leave the owner spotted me.  He was very disappointed but also said they had no seats and advised me to go to the next block where there were one or two places that were OK.  Before I got more than ten steps away, he called me back.  A couple were leaving.  While I waited he brought me a glass of wine -- on him.  Maybe it was because I'm as gray-haired and aging as he.  No matter.  The chicken _______ with a cream sauce was very good, but not as great as the hospitality.  I'll be back.

B0HdQpTzxsgbZK2pQaX-mw.text: As you would expect from a restaurant in town, this place can be loud, crowded and a bit rushed but it has the candlelight ambience and tasty food that could transport you to Italy for a few hours of romance.

NxluEqF95AGt-J_c2JwhHw.text: Went here one night with the wife and had an excellent and romantic dinner.  The prices are very reasonable for London.  However the food is fantastic!  Be sure to start off with the "garlic bread", which is more like a pizza with just marinara sauce, perfectly crispy and delicious.  We also had their pesto linguine which was very tasty.  The wait staff can be a little rushed, but the place gets packed, so you can't blame them.  Try and be ready with your order when they arrive.  Oh yes, the decor is worth mentioning, they have murals painted on the walls of popular italian sites.  Very memorable experience and can't wait to return again!

QcMuIXJyDwcdNW4WI2pDtg.text: Within two weeks of first visiting, I came back to Ciao Bella. Everything I said in my first review holds true, and what follows here are more details from a second visit.I can't say enough good things about this place:  it's a great atmosphere; it's local; it's good food; the servings are generous; it's well-priced (pizzas and pastas for £7); they give you free starters of olives and parmesan. Contrary to many Yelp reviews, I find the waiters here to be amiable and efficient. This time I ordered the canneloni with spinach and ricotta, and it was as hearty and flavorful as my pesto linguine was. A friend ordered a pizza, which had a medium-thick crust and a robust tomato sauce. The pizzas and the calzones are big enough for two kind-of-hungry people or one hungry student. House wine starts at £12 per bottle.We barely got in without a reservation on a Friday night around 7:30, so make sure to book in advance if you want to go on the weekend. On a weeknight, however, it's less crowded and you needn't make a reservation.

U9gqCUd0FebecgiPV46v4w.text: Ciao Bella is perfect for groups- it is cheap, fun and they have large round tables, big enough for 10 people. As soon as you sit down, they give you plates of large chunks of parmesan cheese, olive oil and bread sticks (the service is quite slow so you will be glad of it)If you can, book ahead as it gets extremely busy- it is a very popular restaurant and is constantly filled with families and large groups. If they are full, they might try and put you downstairs, which definitely isn't as nice. Try and get upstairs next to the window so you can look out onto Lamb's Conduit Street or near the piano (if you are lucky/unlucky they will be playing)The food is excellent- I can't have cow's milk (boo) but am a massive fan of pizzas and was extremely impressed when they offered to make me up a calzone with buffallo mozzerella. It was delicious.

Visiting London , as we do every year, has made Ciao Bella ourfavourite place to eat. qwqM6l2D-Cc0RgKnEVApuQ.text: The food was really good. Service was good but a little slow at times. Really great late evening alfresco dining.

UAt9M9Cxh2QW2gDwth_dFA.text: Lamb was to die for. Service didn't meet my expectations for such place.

nrLWdjc7ab-LO4FVXTFAJA.text: I'm not from the area but was traveling through the area. I'm originally from California and was in need of some Pasta.... I found that Ciao Bella was much more than just pasta, it was an assortment of great tastes and excellent food delivery. I highly recommend Ciao Bella for anyone looking for some real flavorable dishes.

g__8uHU21C47nXftmD3jAQ.text: This place is super-solid.  On a Tuesday eve this place was hopping--the outdoor space, the main floor, the basement.  And that is because it is solid.  I was warned that the pizza was just okay but the pasta was the specialty.  They had a great offering of classic pasta and risotto dishes.  It wasn't Italy, but my pasta with broccoli was good and the dishes around me looked amazing.  The house wine was great too.  Liked the vibe--happening, festive, lively.....everything that is great about an Italian restaurant.

8VHRpfa-Hgsl20r-WtTDmA.text: Reasonably priced Italian food near Russell Square.  Definitely not the best Italian food I've had but it was very good.The tables are very close together and it is extremely loud inside - can't hear others in your party talking so you end up screaming at each other all night...We had:  Spaghetti alla Bolognese, Penne all'Arrabbiata, Veal Saltimbocca, Insalata di Rucola & Parmigiana, Fresh Salmon with Onion and Red Wine Sauce and Bruschetta.  Everything was good - they did better with the main courses than with the pasta dishes.Pasta dishes are very reasonable in price, but the mains are a bit more expensive.  It was a great time except for the noise level.Service was just okay.May or may not return in the future - probably only if invited.

IiaI_-Ys7HH3gRO66pKEBA.text: A lovely restaurant. Lovely lovely. After walking past a couple of times and seeing everyone so happy and smelling delicious Italian smells, I went in and my life changed for the better. Everything on the menu is delicious. The pastas, the pizzas, the mains, the wines - all delicious. It's a general Italian menu, so they have your usual selection of pizza margherita, spaghetti bolognese, and bruschetta alongside more Italian dishes like osso bucco and calf's liver. They also have gluten-free pasta on hand, as many Italians are celiacs.It's really a neighborhood place: the best time to come is Sunday afternoon, when families who have just been at the children's park at the end of Lamb's Conduit come for lunch. Also, it seems like the waiters have certain hiring requirements (besides being Italian): have a potbelly, have a mustache, be partly balding, and know how to unnecessarily assist a lady up the stairs. My Italian friend likes this place so much that we just went again with her Italian boyfriend (so you know it's authentic!)The only issue I have is with the downstairs dining room. Upstairs and outside are fine, but downstairs is cramped and noisy and frequently overheated. I'd recommend making a reservation at busy times (7-9 pm, weekend lunch) to avoid getting stuck down there.

Ja8Bwfkm5PatsfGECF4MFQ.text: My friend being me here for the first time yesterday. The spaghetti was really good. I had the seafood one with white sauce. It came out with a big paper bag and the stuff will help you to get the food out. It looks really cool. My friend had the lobster one which is also amazing and big. However I don't think the service is fantastic so I have 4 stars.

iTv2oqW5rIvrfwa9sCddTQ.text: Delicious Italian food. Great prices. Fast service.

mYHknsXdxVI205Qw1TheqA.text: As we all know - only one thing is important when you go for an Italian meal. You want an authentic Italian family screaming at each other. Now, I don't care if it's real - of if they hire a bunch of Italian actors. I just want to feel like I'm in a mafia movie. This is exactly why we take girls to Italian restaurants for dates. The girl can soak up all the candle and romance nonsense; whilst we're entertained by imagining Al Pacino is going to bust in any second with a gun. This is why I love Ciao Bella so much. You can get a seat literally right by the kitchen. It appears to be family owned - I assume this because there are always a bunch of Italian people arguing by the cash register. But please, don't be put off. It's not like when us English argue, all bitter and annoying. It's Italian style; it adds flair to the restaurant. And luckily, the food tastes awesome. My reason for finding the restaurant was quite a sad one. Someone I love was in Great Ormond Street Hospital next door for quite a while. But, this restaurant was so great that for a few hours at a time - our stresses and worries would be lifted. We were in Italy. Sipping wine, eating AGNELLO alle CASTAGNE - and for us males, a mafia movie fantasy being fulfilled. It can be loud, it can be quiet. It can be romantic, it can be all hustle and bustle. It's a restaurant that changes and somehow seems to magically adapt to your needs. But more than anything the important thing to know is that the portions are generous and it all tastes amazing.

XXJ8nzixFxnArBxe4uxsqA.text: A sweet, tasty family restaurant in an interesting (if off the beaten tourist track) part of London.  Kinda noisy and crowded, but the piano player was a lovely touch!  Completely random decor.Pastas carbonara and arrabiata were both plentiful and delicious, and prices very reasonable.Be sure to get the red wine--and make it an Italian bottle! Our server gave us much good-natured grief for choosing a Spanish one.Would definitely recommend for a good value, and if I lived in London I'd totally go back!  Just not a place to have a really intimate evening.

qkY-_axVR8nPC33to38p7A.text: The first night in London and I met up with my girls for a wonderful meal at one of their favorite haunts, Ciao Bella. Once seated, we were greeted by the owner (who immediately recognized my friends) and promptly given a coupon for a percentage off our meal. Excellent!Then we took some time to peruse the menu (which was mainly Italian pasta and fantastic desserts) before deciding. Let me say that our meal was FANTASTIC. Amazing pasta with large portions. I adore the desserts as I had some of their gelato while my friends shared a ginormous dessert concoction. The service was brusque but whatever, I'm here to enjoy hanging out with my friends and having a wonderful conversation filled with laughter and good food. This more than fits the bill!I definitely recommend coming here a bit early. It gets crowded quickly so grab a spot with a date or some good friends and settle in for a great evening.

EXwdTL5wWqr7kD3Z11Eeyw.text: Spectacular for maintaining a feel good Italian grumpy smiley local cosmopolitan organized chaos with good ingredients. Will eat there again. The proprietor's son's haircut is a sensation! Wondering if he will survive the fallout.

A0eTKDgLbKRTyh7MtrVqaA.text: Man, oh, man, this place is fantastic.  So hearty, so tasty.  Such a great neighborhood place.  Wish there was a cookbook by the folks that run this place.  Don't think twice - just go.

SerRgkxqGuBmsKEjWE0n8A.text: Has a genuine homely feel and is clearly well established. The food is simple but great quality and generously portioned. My Irish Coffee was the best I've had in ages. Would definitely go back.

wa_84VuV9zD6Mv1E4gp_EA.text: Ciao Bella is the gift that keeps on giving. First they give you free mixed and spiced olives, delicious little chunks of parmesan cheese, and breadsticks. NICE. Then they generally give you pretty abrupt and brusque service, all the more to get you sitting, ordering, eating, and leaving quickly. Not quite as nice. However, they more than make up for it by giving you amazing, fresh-cooked, well-priced, ridiculously tasty pasta. The massive plate of linguine with pesto for £7 is so good that I left the restaurant and immediately began discussing when we could return so I could eat it again. REALLY NICE. And remember the not-so-nice part? They tried to hurry us along by giving us someone else's order, but then apologised by giving us free pizza bread. So much to give. The only problem in my book? Ciao Bella gives you such crazy garlic breath that you could slay an army of bloodthirsty vampires with a single exhale. Give it a few minutes before you make out with anyone.

h7QW8o16BvH5TOYZMFfxMw.text: I get pasta carbonara everywhere I go, including Florence a few weeks ago, and this is HANDS DOWN the best I've ever had. Service was great, and the house red wine was pretty good for £3.75. Would 100% recommend.

zoRPejh1-FEmDCJPM3AI1A.text: If you are looking for an enjoyable dining, then Ciao Bella is the place.   The food&atmosphere were very good classic Italian.   It was just a lovely dining experience!!!

tnFSQftVW8qOn1cKfQfY_g.text: Very cheap and good atmosphere but the wine tasted homebrewed, maybe my fault for letting the waiter chose. The bruscetta was tasty but very far from anything that an Italian would eat. Maybe I have been in Italy and gotten spoiled earlier though. Had the seafood pasta which was very taste. Gave an extra point for it. Just hope I do not food poisoning.There was a piano player there the evening I went which was nice.

6rpM0_2vhoOpY6BbYrMd5g.text: Having moved away from the UK, I find myself salivating at the thought of Ciao Bella's food whilst reminiscing, teary eyed, about the good times I've had at this place. Good thing my friends and I have already put Ciao Bello on our list of things to do when I make my visit next month!Great nights often started at this restaurant. It was the combination of cheap wine, great food, and warm atmosphere that puts people in the right mood to be adventurous in roaming the city after dinner. The restaurant is compact, so you tend to get a bit intimate with those around you. Also, there might be quite a wait during dinner time, but you can easily slip on over to the pub next door (The Lamb??) for a few drinks as you wait. Once seated, you are greeted with olives, cheese and breadsticks, but be careful not to spoil your appetite. My personal favourite was the seafood pasta that came in a greaseproof bag. Sadly, I always order too much, yet too little...meaning I'd fill myself up on olives and either the avocado vinaigrette or avocado prawn cocktail. All this before my pasta even arrives... not to mention the wine. Did I mention their wine is cheap?

heJjqmf2Ul1q94MRk4t-0g.text: I went to Ciao Bella with friends a few days ago, when we needed a dinner break. Strangely, though I've been to most of the places on Lambs Conduit and have enjoyed them, I'd never tucked into Ciao Bella before.We sat outside, which was nice since the weather was good, though it's always frustrating to have cigarette smoke wafting over you as you try and enjoy a good meal (there were perpetrators at both my table and others, so I can't totally complain, but it's still a detriment to the outside option!).The food was really good--though I unfortunately couldn't finish the huge portion they brought me. I had the spaghetti carbonara and was very pleased with it. The prices were good too, for the portion size. It's a lovely authentic Italian place, and certainly one of the better ones I've tried in London. Definitely a good spot if you're looking to carbo-load with some good pasta.

0CVQG7bu0pg6al2Z-YBzhg.text: My friends and I recently came here for a friends birthday. We didn't have a reservation, but they allowed us to sit outside. It was chilly and raining outside, but they had heaters and an awning that made it comfortable enough to sit outside. I can't give this place the best rating because the service was really disappointing. After standing awkwardly in the doorway while the waitress chatting with another employee, she finally acknowledged us. After telling her we didn't have a reservation, she made a noticeable sigh and told us that we should have one - sorry.. Then when she said we could sit outside, our waiter was noticeably annoyed to be serving us. He took our order in a hurry and didn't even ask what we would like to drink - we had to remind him. He was also incredibly hard to get the attention of. Granted the restaurant was very crowded, but then he was obviously overworked and someone should be helping him manage all the tables! We also asked for our check multiple times until finally a different woman brought it out for us. The seating outside is incredibly crowded as well. You can't get out without bothering everyone around you.The food is this place's redeeming factor however. I got the pasta w/ clams, and it was very delicious. All my friends got either another pasta or pizza, and they all were extremely satisfied as well. Overall, the food was good enough to make us forget about the subpar service.

Lleguxu-rklL-hIlWaO2uQ.text: Pretty great Italian food for being in the middle of Bloomsbury, London! I had the Linguine alle vongole (w/ clams). Perfecto! Great consistency with the linguine, not overcooked and not too raw. The white wine sauce was on point with garlic, and the clams were pretty much fresh. Service was excellent, and the place is pretty lively for a Sunday night in London filled with people. Most restaurants are closed on Sundays in London, but this one is poppin'.Oh, it's def legit when the piano guy was playing the Godfather's theme song and had the whole restaurant do the singalong. Too legit!!

uVnmnwW2DsxWcWQ0qYSlyw.text: We use this restaurant all the time as a place to come for work do's. I've enjoyed it so much I've introduced my friends and family to it too! The food is cheap and tasty and the portions are large. There is so much choice on the menu and the waiters are efficient but friendly. The place is always packed. in summer it is nigh impossible to get a table after 7 unless you have booked, on any day of the week. Rupert Everett, Jon Snow and the red arrows have all been spotted here (by me and others) over the years! Couldn't recommend it enough except to say, book early, ask for the table outside and order the cheesy garlic bread to start!

vKkNOULsMWiHKVwvvt3v5Q.text: Excellent food and big fun! Bf and I are in town for a few days and staying in Bloomsbury. I've never stayed in this hood, so was excited to check out spots. The high star reviews are fair and appropriate. Firstly, the spot was packed and buzzing when we arrived at 10 or so. Very good vibe. Seemed that every seat inside and outside were taken-we were happy to get sat immediately. As we walked in, the person who turned out to be our server was NOOOOOTTTT happy with the hostess, let her know and continued with her busy tables without missing a beat. Was awesome.As we sat munching on breadsticks (bf munched on the olives placed on the table-he said they were delicious), I marveled at the packed house; some two tops, four tops and a few huge parties and how they were all being served with ease. The spot is very West Village...buzzing with Italian being yelled across tables, fabulous aromas, good looking wine and American cinema kitsch EVERYWHERE. So much to see! Love the Stevie Wonder piece above the piano! Oh yes-when we arrived, there was this cat crooning as he played piano. Very cool. I can't agree about what others describe as "noisy", but then again-I'm noisy. Bf and I were all in the business of the couple next to us-I can't tell you how amazing the pizza looked! I mean...we wanted to ask for a bite. We only didn't order pizza because I felt like having pasta for the first time...dunno. Months easy. I never eat pasta. I ordered my fave-linguni with nothing but steamed broccoli. The broc (my fave food) was seriously just picked. SO fresh!!! Bf said his lasagna was amazing.Finally, it's so freakin' beyond reasonably priced. Cheap.The dessert menu was pretty cool. I never eat dessert, but was happy to see some mainstays that reminded me of old school Italian spots when I was little.This spot is a must.

zRDcY_RLlgeky4aYNoZxEQ.text: Excellent service and great brick oven pizza!! Brought my parents here from NY and they agree the American hot pizza is something they will crave when they go back!

CPdFUg8W9Qq0ydCWVXu0JA.text: For the price (very reasonable) this is one of the best places for Italian. The only negative is it gets extremely busy, definitely recommend making a reservation.

_pUE1RlZ9qaQT8E3TNtZWg.text: This place is ace. This is an Italian as a family-run Italian restaurant can ever get, guys. UW0a1V3XB0x0qGZ71jiyYA.text: When you live near Little Italy, you tend to know some good Italian. And on my walks home from campus, the buzzing outside crowd caught my attention each time. When it's cold outside and you have people willing to sit outside anyway, you know this place it quite special. I can say this was quite decent. Like other ethnic restaurants, when the staff, clientele and menus are in the language, I tend to believe a little more than otherwise. Which is the case here. All in all I would return for a lovely time.

hlvJmpwnaZl-4w92Xi6wFg.text: classic little italian in a great location. went here based on the huge number of decent reviews. i'll back them up.£35 for olives, bread, cheese, 2 pastas - the clams were plentiful, the meatballs may have had more breadcrumbs than meat (reason for 4 not 5 stars) but the spaghetti was beautiful and the sauce big on the garlic...hmmmm. and the house red was perfectly drinkable.service classic italian style, simple enough, pleasant. could be part of a perfect evening in bloomsbury, hitting a few stores on lambs conduit, bite to eat at ciao bella and a few beers to wash it down in the local pub. nice. oh the al fresco seating was plenty warm enough to watch the street go by.

wvZXNfHdWyfJfjgSf6IfVg.text: With all of this restaurant's good reviews, I was expecting better.  I knew that service would be rushed, since I came in without a reservation, but I didn't expect it to be this bad.  I came in and they wanted to seat me right next to the door on a cold night.  I declined politely, so they seated me farther in the entry room, and warned me that I had to be out within an hour.  They then proceeded to open the door (presumably to air the place out) - it got cold!  Worse yet, we got wafts of cigarette smoke coming from outside.  They finally closed it when asked, but seriously...?During this full process, service was not friendly or warm at all.  It was efficient enough, but they barely said a word when serving the food.  The most I heard from the waiters was when they were standing around laughing boisterously at a YouTube video. Unprofessional!I ordered the onion soup (mediocre) and the seafood spaghetti in a bag.  The latter was disappointing as well.  The pasta was fresh, but the white sauce was oily and watery.  I wasn't impressed particularly.I wouldn't recommend this place, although perhaps I just caught them on a bad day.

Xge-Vj1v0utZFEBt8sTXow.text: When I first moved to London as a student WAY BACK AS MANY YEARS AGO AS IT TAKES TWO HANDS TO COUNT Ciao Bella was the "fancy, celebration" restaurant we'd go to.  Post-exams.  Final goodbye at the end of the year.  Ciao Bella was the ticket.  It was great, and we'd sit outside as a loud group of students, smoking cigarettes and eating massive pizzas and sipping wine and feeling very smug and sophisticated.Power forward ahead: I love Lambs Conduit and many of the new incarnations along the strip, but just have never had a recent opportunity to revisit Ciao Bella.  Until I recognized the same Italian man outside and decided to, well...pop in.  And make a reservation.  And...it was lovely.The service - which several reviews mention as brusque - is.  It is, totally, brusque.  But not in a harsh way, and certainly not in a targeted way: that's just how they operate.  Equal opportunity brusqueness!  Also: don't go here to break up with someone.  Or to tell them a secret.  YOU WILL BE PACKED IN TIGHT WITH YOUR NEIGHBOUR.  Especially if you sit out on the patio under the heat lamps (which you should).Food is hearty, good, not fancy Italian fare.  For the portion sizes, I think totally affordable (I always have leftovers or - pro tip - go for 1/2 portions of pasta, which they are happy to do for all but the seafood options).  Veal meatballs?  Delish.  Pizzas topped with an egg or, perhaps, with pear and blue cheese?  Yep, sure.  They also do more traditional mains like veal cutlet, or stuffed chicken breast...I've only nicked some of both from friends' plates and they were good (special shout-out to the veg which are never mushy or overcooked) but I always stick to a pizza / pasta option.  Oh, and the tricolore salad with mozzarella, tomatoes and avocado, a spritz of lemon, some pepper and lashings of olive oil.  That PLUS the freebie olives, hunks of parmesan and breadsticks and, well...prepare to roll home.Yelp note: reservations highly recommended (though if you have a wee wait, The Lamb and The Perserverance are both good bets)

MQzOpidTBAVhWruJVzqU0A.text: Nice food and friendly staff. Had a great time dining out in Ciao Bella. As soon as we got into the restaurant, they provided us with their wifi password, which was so considerate.

uf4IdTxPDCdUEQLHNxaoWw.text: Too successful for their own good makes my review a small ripple in an ocean of customers. The food and house red wine are generally good. The service split between my two visits ranged from prompt but indifferent to could be quite good but is either too busy or too undertrained in service or, possibly, English. Really, Ciao Bella is worth a visit and, for the most part, will not disappoint, provided you temper your expectations. And remember, a packed house can't be wrong. Right?That your arrival is greeted with cheese, bread sticks and olives is a really nice touch, especially when you arrive hungry. You will be greeted promptly and offered libations in that same breath. Drinks will be brought quickly and, at that time, you'll be queried for your order. If you're not yet ready, checking back may take awhile, and this will be a running theme. Stages in the course of your visit are generally executed rapid fire; except check backs. And this includes the main course. There was an issue with my entree making it inedible to me. Despite having consumed everything but the entree, and with salad plate still lingering, a staff member swooped  in to grab my plate, while in motion asking if  I was finished. When I tried to explain that I hadn't even started, because ... The plate was set back down with a comment about letting me take me time. This missed the point entirely, and before I could explain, this person quickly vanished. Let's be clear here: they made it right, but not without some effort and frustration. I truly think they mean well and want you to enjoy your meal. However, they seem to lack a certain amount of polish and adequate staffing. That said, I still recommend Ciao Bella. As long as you know what you're in for, you'll likely have an enjoyable experience again and again.

o1zl2nwkC0WXgZXKNHhJEQ.text: This is a great old fashioned Italian eatery.By old fashioned, I mean literally. I'm Italian and I remember growing up surrounded by loud Uncles who always seemed to be fighting. As I got older I realized nobody was really mad, it's just the way they talked to each other.That describes the atmosphere her perfectly. I love it!There is a fun piano player and singer that runs through his favorite songs while looking around for some acknowledgement from the crowd. The pasta is hime made and melts in your mouth. For dessert, chocolate lovers will long crave the Tartufo Nero!Ciao Bella is an easy walk from Russell Street station. If you are in London check it out!

A definite family feel with a great ring of authenticity throughout. The well-painted, but also kitschy murals; the piano man who started playing singing out of nowhere (most of us thought that was a bar - nope, a piano!); the fast-talking no-nonense wait staff - it's all quite nice.I was there with a large party of about 15-20 people for a birthday and they went out of their way to make sure we were all taken care of. 3 people arrived really late (as the rest were beginning to get main courses served) and the kitchen rushed their orders so that the late arrivals still got their main courses before the rest of us had finished. They made a beautiful chocolate birthday cake for our friend who was celebrating. The buffalo mozzarella starter is amazing and every one liked their pizzas and pastas for mains - even if we were all shocked by the portion size! I had pesto linguine and the pesto was really lovely.My only complaint is that by 9:30 or so it was packed and insanely loud. Shouting to the person next to you at dinner is less than ideal.Bonus: actor spotting. That was just something fun.

Ow8Dsozpd91_yOgku-tHiQ.text: This is an unassuming neighbourhood restaurant, that just happens to be in the heart of town. The food is fabulous, including the olives and cheese whisked over to you as appetisers within moments of sitting down. We had a single course of pasta (spaghetti with tapenade, beef ravioli) and glass of a lovely montepulciano from an adorable half-bottle.We had swift service in the early evening, great food and lovely staff (who know some of their customers by name - the sign of a great restaurant). There were some seats outside, and the quiet Lamb's Conduit Street provided a more than adequate backdrop for our bites to eat. Heartily recommended, especially for the reasonable price and great location.

kl6dyQ4_ffcMvDmZUgHyxA.text: Food was excellent. We all had great food and the ambiance was great. One of the waiters was a bit terse, but it was clear that he was very stressed so it's water under the bridge. I would definitely recommend this place.

JqE1oonl9Du2VfMM8Kfnpg.text: I always try to steer clear of simple meals like spaghetti bolognese or carbonara as I like to try new meals that require some difficulty in cooking when dining out, but Ciao Bella's carbonara is so tasty that I never have to spend time browsing the menu as it's such an easy choice. Their portions are generous, and I really love that all the waiters and staff are italian which gives the place a nice authentic vibe. I would recommend booking a table upstairs as the downstairs area is very squeezed for space in comparison to the more spacious and lively top floor.

tgd2lQcMeZE9dLpmRrYfNA.text: Ciao Bella is the real deal.You'll no doubt be squeezed into a table, elbow to elbow with your neighbours (because they seem to always be full unless you eat about 9.30pm) and your waiter will rush you along almost like he doesn't want you to be there. But don't be put off by that, don't rush, he'll come back once you're ready to order. It's almost an initiation test!The food here is fantastic. Obviously fresh, super tasty and quite reasonably priced too. They'll give you some olives and cheese to nibble on whilst you decide what you want and they're a good omen - great olives and crumbly parmesan. Not at all bad for free.Shared a couple of starters; some juicy bruschetta (seasoned perfectly) and 3 large sardines, which were grilled and the spines came away with ease - leaving no bones at all. Colour me very happy at this stage. For a main I went for a special - the rabbit with pappardelle - mostly because it's my favourite type of pasta. And it was huge. I think I had half a rabbit on my plate. My friend went for the seafood spaghetti and it's served in a brown bag and practically poured onto your plate at the table. Nice touch.The wine list here is a weighty tome, so if you know your reds you're in for a treat.Overall, great experience and would love to come back. It's not at all fancy, so you can dress as casual or as smart as you like. Try and grab an outside seat in the summer!

03f3pK9abRvup-Yx_urTGg.text: We went to Ciao Bella because the other Italian food restaurant we we're planning to eat at was closed for the May Bank Holiday. We saw that Ciao Bella was opened and decided to try it out. We showed up right at noon when they were opening, but there was already a large gathering of what looked to be "regulars" on the front patio area. They were also all speaking Italian, so we thought that was a good sign! However, our server was indifferent at best with us, while he cracked jokes with his regulars. We truly felt like he didn't want us there. The food we ended up eating was mediocre and I probably could have made better at home. My husband got the cannelloni, which was bland, and I got the carbonara, which had a broken sauce and overcooked pasta. There are plenty of better Italian food options elsewhere in London.

C93rMx36oG-gH0hXYd07YQ.text: Came in as a party of 8 (including four hungry teens) from a rainy, cold London post-British Museum. Mid-week lunch rush, no reservations. Having only read about Ciao Bella on Yelp and knowing it was a relatively close walk from the museum, I dutifully led my large party to the restaurant, hoping for the best. It did not disappoint.Despite the restaurant being packed, the owner was more than gracious when I told him of our party size. He immediately called existing reservations to see if they were showing up (some were, some were not). Ultimately, the best he could do (and he did it quickly) was to split us up into multiple tables, which we gratefully accepted.As others have noted, the food is really excellent and authentic (the staff appear to be all part of the same Italian family and the owners). The portions are large, service was brisk and friendly, and the price, more than reasonable. We were in and out in less than 45 minutes and didn't feel rushed at all. In terms of standout food, oddly enough, the spaghetti Bolognese was particularly good - light and filled with flavor. Overall, the kitchen there really knows how to cook pastas of all kinds, which makes an enormous difference for Italian food. Will absolutely go back when I'm next in London.

aekeDoPWEmF-1PlkYc_Q9A.text: Came here on a Sunday night. The bagged bread sticks are a bit tacky but we were served complimentary olives and cheese which was very tasty. There was a live piano player, but it was too hot inside so we asked to sit outside. They have outdoor seating, two rooms of dining on the main floor and another seating area downstairs, so they can definitely handle parties of all sizes. Bring the whole family! The first impression we got was there are a lot of regulars here... made me a bit jealous... guess I'll have to come more often. We started off with the night's special Calamari. I saw the word calamari and just ordered it. I didn't read the description, I just knew I wanted it, and it was D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S. It isn't your typical fried calamari with boring marinara sauce and tartar sauce or even the very over played but still delicious chargrilled calamari. It was slightly spicy for flavor and a bit soupy. There is no separation of the squid, just the whole squid cooked in the sauce. If they have this on the menu still. Get it. Then we had the tagliatelle "ciao bella" which was very good for the first few bits. Creamy and wonderful. But the more I ate the more I felt it was a bit salty and the presentation a bit disappointing. The salmon was broken up into small pieces which to me makes it look like the dish was for a very large child.... which I am so I was fine with it, but if you're big on presentation because you need something to put on your Instagram, don't order this. We also got the spaghetti cob polpette which I liked better. The tomato sauce tastes so fresh and sweet and the spaghetti noodles were cooked perfectly. The meatballs were also delicious! I would recommend this. We ended with the Pana cotta and a shot of limoncello. I personally didn't like the sauce with the Pana Cotta, it was a bit too tart but the rest was great. A man sitting next to us got a pasta dish served in a bag and poured at the table.... I REALLY want to come back and try this out. The service is friendly and quick. If you want real Italian food with a family feel, I absolutely recommend this place!

L5-go8gqxbVUIJbJb-gWvw.text: Came here on someone's recommendation that the food was good but little else. I can confirm this to be accurate. I walked up at 11:56am to ask if they were open ahead of meeting my friend. The man did not look up but said, 'in a few minutes' half under his breath. I might have taken this differently if he bothered to greet me, or even make eye contact but as it was, he continued to set the tables inside, while a row of 15 tables were already set and begging for company just outside. If I hadn't already agreed on the place with my friend, I would have moved on. When my friend arrived at 5 past, we asked for seats outdoors, and a woman brusquely pointed us to one at the far end and said we could have it for an hour and a half. We took it gratefully and were brought water glasses shortly after with some olives and cheese. We put in an order for spaghetti vongole and linguine alfredo with another dour server who did not offer a smile in the brief interaction we had. The food came quickly and was indeed delicious but not anything all that special. They sprinkled pepper on the dishes with a look of contempt. From there we enjoyed our meal in peace and at the hour, asked for our bill. The total came to £24 which included a service charge - I chuckled at the presumption and coughed it up to cover the olives and cheese offering. The place was indeed buzzy with activity - not sure if this was largely due to the beautiful weather out or if this was actually a favorite for regular patrons. Either way, I would not recommend it and would suggest you keep on down Lambs Conduit for other places of business that will welcome you appropriately.

RFOq3Xebuq5DVMPV_xCXHA.text: The restaurant isn't in a very happening location (on a side street along a hospital), but don't let that deter you. As soon as you walk through the door, the interior is lively, full of people laughing and talking, and you get a blast of wonderful aromas. It's like an Italian wedding, in the best of ways. Best of all, you can hear people inside speaking in Italian (both the customers and staff), which means you're in for the real deal! The staff are very accommodating, so that's a nice touch also.The menu is rather touristy (i.e., mostly common dishes like spaghetti with clams, penne arrabbiata, etc.), but everything looks to be done well even if it's not super unique. The portions are fairly large, but you'll have a tough time stopping when you're full. For the cannelloni, both the tomato and bechamel were quite good by themselves, and just elevated to a whole new level together. Several good options for wine that are all reasonably priced.I would definitely recommend going here. It's not one of the "cool" restaurants in Covent Garden, but it's fun and the food is solid.

iEyB7F7cVfMRFP70bkxvNg.text: What a lovely surprise at the top end of Lamb's Conduit Street - they don't make them like this anymore!! We walked past all the trendier and hipper places to come across this little place - actually, it's not all that little as they cram them in downstairs too and some diners even braved the winter cold to sit outside (under heaters).There used to be a fair few of these traditional Italian restaurants all over London, run by families and serving honest home style dishes. Ciao Bella is one of the few left and draws in a good crowd.The flipside are large groups of office workers who come here after work. We ended up next to a group of loud and drunk men who didn't even apologise when they spilled their red wine all over my friend. All saved by the caring staff and you can't blame a restaurant for its rowdy clientele.Recommended if you are in need of some proper comfort food - I'll definitely be back, my penne arrabbiata was cooked to perfection.

pjaC3b0MG-1-Cujbesr8PQ.text: This was one of the best pasta dishes I've ever had! Granted I don't eat a lot of italian food but I ordered the linguine al pesto and it was amazing. There was an extremely generous portion for a reasonable price, noodles cooked perfectly, incredibly creamy pesto sauce that really coated the noodles, and there were PINE NUTS AND CASHEWS IN IT. What a REVOLUTIONARY IDEA where was this when I was eating italian food all my life...Also the ambience is great, very friendly staff, talented albeit exuberant pianist.

XYQf_Z9LavM1JwQ0uCwGaw.text: Excellent neighbourhood Italian. Broad range of choices and very affordable. The food is tasty but the best part of this place is it's atmosphere. Always busy and has a wonderful electric vibe. The staff are friendly, attentive and the pianist really adds to the ambience.

yd9CHgpt69nF1L55TN1JEA.text: 37 minute rushed experience here in June 2017.We arrived for a 7pm reservation and were seated right away at 7.01pm. Our table was right in the middle of the busy restaurant with only 2 inches, no exaggeration, 2 inches on either side of our table from the ones next to us. We were sandwiched in between two other couples. The closeness of the tables made it very awkward and difficult to have a conversation with my partner.I had barely opened the menu when a waiter appeared to ask what we wanted to drink. I said we hadn't had time to look yet and asked for some water for the table in the meantime.Within a minute a different waiter had appeared at to ask the same question. We told them we had just placed an order for water with one of their colleagues.Within a few further minutes (before I had finished reading their 2-page menu) a different waiter arrived to ask us what we would like to eat. We ordered some pasta dishes, and two drinks.Within a minute the drinks arrived, and within 5 the food arrived suspiciously quickly. We ate, and I had barely put my cutlery down when the plates were whisked away and we were presented with the desert menu.Deciding we didn't want anything, we were told "just the bill, yes?". It duly arrived. I placed my card inside and within 30 seconds a different waiter yet again had arrived to take my payment.We left the restaurant within 37 minutes at 7.38pm. This was not the relaxing evening dinner that we had planned.The food was ok. I've been to a 100 Italian restaurants with a comparable menu and food quality but none with the same fast-food rush dining experience.

wfEWhDchaVS-fXWXvMtqgw.text: We are staying at Saco and went there as it is close. I have to say it is awesome. The only downside it is small and the seating inside is tight. You will need a reservation but the food is great!!

LGAChGSGfxGaaNRfVPWJFg.text: We went on a Saturday night and this place was heaving! Total mental! We got a table, just about, but the seating is too cramped and so the waiters accidentally were knocking my coat off the chair!  Food wise, I went for the lobster spaghetti and it was just average. The lobster was fresh and tasted good, but the spaghetti massively lacked flavour! A case of pass me the garlic ASAP! My dad loved his lasagne, so maybe it was just a case of me ordering the wrong thing. At £17 for the dish though, I was expecting it to be like the crem de crem of dishes... I got a glass of the house red and it wasn't bad.. Nothing special, but for £4, it hardly blows the budget! All in all, I left feeling rather let down.. Maybe because I heard so many good things about this place, but I certainly won't be running back.

BcVYhu-UGlABjzMx4Lvo1Q.text: This place is everything you want from an Italian restaurant: great staff (mainly Italian), buzzing atmosphere and over 50 menu choices including about 14 different pastas. AND most importantly on busier nights someone bashes out tunes on the grand piano. All the food is pretty authentically Italian however they do let you put Parmesan on fish based pastas (punishable by lynching in Italy). There are wood oven pizzas, antipasto starters, mains and pasta (obviously). Not too many surprises here just really well done classics with a heap of garlic and flavour. There's no wonder that on Friday you often have to line. We shared three pastas: a salmon and broccoli cream base linguini, ricotta ravioli with a safe butter sauce and lastly, broccoli, anchovies and chilli spaghetti. All excellent. Big but not too huge that you feel guilty about wasting half the plate. We also shared a tiramisu which could have used a dash more coffee but was a nice way to finish.  The restaurant had some nice little touches with Parmesan, olives and bread sticks give to you as you sit down and all the staff had personality. Wine list was pretty reasonable and featured all the Italian comfort wines for decent prices. Next time I'll get into the grappa.

PnoOWnBQMeOAiL5NXUa79Q.text: Friendly staff and lively atmosphere!  I have had take out several times while I've been in London from Ciao Bella and I really enjoyed all the dishes I've had so far.

H5lj2GxQ3qlqXty6e6lO2w.text: The staff is really lovely, the pianist is so talented, the food is generous and delicious, its a great location. We've been multiple times and always love it.The pizzas and the pastas are delicious. (My friends gets the carbonara every time and she always loves it.Might want to make a reservation if you're going in the evening!

0cQ-vrzgPPUPD2TExEAXOA.text: Make a reservation, especially if you're a group. This place was packed on a random Wed night at 9pm. Seems to be run by old school Italians. They must have an arrangement with the pub next door, because the nice host managing the wait list encourages you to have a drink there while you wait and explains that he will come find you in the pub once your table is ready.Two drinks and 45 min later we were in.We sat downstairs at this bi-level establishment. Not fancy. Felt very family style. But in a fun and boisterous, not cozy and quaint, way. Once seated, we had to beg them to take our order (granted they are always very busy and customer service in London seems to be driven by the customer being proactive). But beyond worth it once the food arrives. I had the pesto. Portions are large, reasonably priced and of impeccable quality. We also downed 2 extremely reasonably priced bottles of above average house red. And all those amazing desserts in the pic? All mine! I wish...At least I got to sample them all. I prob could have devoured them all, but my friends would have killed me.

vDQ9onSyfp15u6s30tt5kQ.text: A very friendly, cozy place for dinner. We came here on a Friday night to start the weekend. The restaurant has two levels. The upstairs is entertained by a pianist while the downstairs seem a bit rowdier by comparison. We were seated downstairs but apart from being a bit loud, it was actually quite festive and upbeat. For starters, we shared a Margarita pizza that actually reminded me a bit of traditional New York pizza. My entrée was the veal marsala, which I enjoyed very much. I was also happy that they were able to substitute the potatoes with garlic spinach. Just an extra note to the spinach - really loved the strong olive oil and garlic taste. For drinks, we had the house red. It was very good and at a great price. Finally, the desserts did not disappoint. The service was prompt and very friendly. I especially enjoyed the family feel of the restaurant.

HkFRxlrTu0sBkdns6Hmd9w.text: Solid Italian food, solid wine selection (across all prices), decent service, decent value overall. Wish my lamb main-course had been a little larger. Busy atmosphere with a pianist playing an eclectic mix of classic and pop hits. Sit upstairs if you want to enjoy the music!

qZzBZg1DJ4bUfVTTq9dzVQ.text: First we were told no tables for 90 minutes (although half the place was empty) then we went back five min later and they rudely said nothing tonight unless we immediately took a table after we ordered a drink next door at the OUTSTANDING pub The Lamb. Never ate their food but rudeness goes a long way. Do yourself a favor and skip this place - head to the lamb!! Super place!!!

CPhs0IkBOpOQw-2vkFvfsw.text: Ciao Bella is a solid option for Italian in a city not exactly swimming in options.It is family-style: you sit at long, barely separate tables. Everyone can hear your conversation, but that matter little when so much of it is about how good the food is.Let's be clear: Ciao Bella isn't setting the high-bar for Italian worldwide, but it is in the top 10% of London. It full deserve four stars. No more, no less since you can find better here and can certainly find worse. You can tell right from the olives they give you that there is something special, but not sublime going on here. The wine list, with many capable options, isn't going to blow any sommelier's mind, but he wouldn't scoff either.The food is served in healthy portions, is super tasty, and filling. There's lots of variety. The staff are prompt and courteous. Given the decent size of the place and it's more neighborhoody location, you're likely to get a table quickly at all but the busiest hours.All-in-all, a solid option I will be definitely returning for several times.

wc86i4L029M3bKcWzDX2VQ.text: My favourite Italian in London! The food is delicious! Brought some friends over (visiting from overseas and been to all the overpriced and stuffy restaurants) and it was the best Carbonarra they've ever had! Linguine al pesto is amazing and pizzas are always perfect! Live piano in the evenings, pretty busy all the time but service is always great. Strongly recommend.

_r64a6E0bqTZvaRGEcXiwg.text: Inexpensive Italian restaurant with wide ranging menu. Excellent pizza and pasta; decent house wines.

kdE6208J1L46MD1v5-Fhiw.text: I am at Ciao Bella practically every week. It is cheap, cheerful and has a great friendly atmosphere. The quirkiest thing is the sheer number of birthdays that seem to be celebrated at Ciao Bella. On any given Saturday, there are 5-10 renditions of Happy Birthday, played by one of the regular pianists. The pianists are also open to other requests and are particularly keen on audience participation as long as you have a half decent voice.The service can be a little slow, but I like to think that this is due to the staff reading the situation and serving those who are in for the duration more slowly than those trying to grab a quick bite. If you mention that you are in a rush, they are usually accommodating.

wrfcazaQMkQXYGvaILuZog.text: I was taken on a date here a couple of weeks ago, and as your would expect of an Italian, the food was very good.Although the service was slightly cold, i was served by a older man who seemed to have a small chip on his shoulder, although the other staff seemed smiley enough. I had mussles to start with, which was emormous and I could have stopped after that, I found them delicious though my spanish boyfriend had to think Spanish do them better.. urgh medeterrean competition! We sat outside, and even though it was -3, their were patio heaters which made it bearable with a fur coat on! The pizzas were huge, and delicious. There were a friendly and lively group of LSE students next to us, drinking Lemon Cello my favourite!i'd recommend sitting outside for a romantic evening out....

wBcqGIFkAPV-PnkV_Pkbmg.text: Love this place, great food, great atmosphere. It was pretty authentic as far as i could tell. And we had a party of 10, and they managed to squeeze us in last minute. Very gracious....

xUA9Blk0eaFS9chMeN8pjg.text: I haven't actually been to Ciao Bella for an actual sit-down meal. But, I was really impressed with the plate o' yum I had the other day during the Lamb's Conduit Christmas Street Fair. For a mere five quid I got a plateful of meatballs, roast pork (with homemade crisps) and a breaded chicken drumstick. Each item on said plate was dee-lish! This friendly, local Italian resto is now top of my list for the next time I go out for a nice meal. Ciao Bella is steps from one of my favourite pubs too - The Lamb! Yay. People whose judgement I trust, such as Qyper JuliePH (qype.co.uk/people/JuliePH) , speak highly of this place too! Hmmm ... need to get back there asap.

nteEg2pcwGPpSV_B3YOEWw.text: Huge portions at prices which put the Carluccio's around the corner to shame! The place gets really busy in the evenings and at lunchtimes and I've never seen it more than a couple of empty seats. Well worth making a reservation if you're planning to come with more than one or two others. The starters and the calzone, in particular, are delicious. Service is attentive and good-humoured and the meals don't take that long to arrive, particularly given the number of people ordering. I've been there plenty of times in the past and will undoubtedly do so again in the future! EDIT: definitely book ahead, especially on a Friday night, which I've seen get fully booked 2 days in advance. Also had a bad experience with mussels here, but once in 10/15 visits leads me to believe it was more of a one-off.

eQ9A_sRlZxk9w3qRidB7zQ.text: I love this place.The food is good, the prices are great, the people are accommodating.Sure, it's a little hard to get a table, but that should tell you something about how good the restaurant is.I love that most of the people you see are old men in suits or young college students.  A great deal is to be had here.I'm from New York, and this reminds me a New York italian restaurant.

JpD0iVEF91ZOytaTYvFoYA.text: A friend and I visited Ciao Bella in mid January I had never been there before and it was a last minute decision on a Wednesday night. They were busy but the man who greeted us warmly at the door told us to pop into the pub next door for 20-30 minutes and he would come and get us. 20 or so minutes later he duly came in, carried our drinks and led us to his restaurant and our table. I can be a hearty eater at times and this was the first time in a while that I have been overwhelmed, we shared a starter of lovely garlic bread starter which we couldn't finish and when my pizza arrived it was awesome and tasted spot on. The staff were friendly and cheerful and I do think the man who looked after us went well beyond the call of duty in coming to collect us form the pub. I would definitely go back and it would be churlish not to give it anything other than full marks.

BdsJ6uiufI62h0QxJQOs7A.text: This is place is always very busy so that's a very good sign. it's in a lovely part of bloomsbury and has some very good pubs nearby (Lamb and flag next door is superb). The food is fairly priced and of good quality considering the amount they produce. I do prefer a more intimate venue (like L'osteria) but saying that there is nothing wrong with Ciao Bella.

VXmGdxX_liow3AuwRLefnQ.text: I have been to Ciao Bella on many occasions ranging from romantic dinner for two to a full takeover of the terrace for a birthday celebration one Sunday that ended with my friend at the baby grand piano and a grand old singalong. Fabulous! Everything I've tried on the menu  has been delicious, especially the pizzas, but my favourite is the seafood spaghetti pasta that is cooked in the oven in a paper bag and then brought to your table and tipped with an aromatic flourish in to your bowl by an over the top Italian waiter. You do have to book ahead  Friday and Saturday, Sunday and even Thursday evenings. It does get very busy which is great if you're upstairs enjoying the hustle-bustle but not great if you end up downstairs which is a little claustrophobic and en route to the loos. If you meeting people, start your evening at the Lamb pub right next door, an award-winning delight of a boozer.  But my advice is to plan ahead and book a table outside for you and your friends to while a whole Sunday afternoon eating more carbs than is ever good for you and getting slowly drunk on red wine and the inevitable Grappas.

j1ikx4hZxbu7B6CR-LnMjA.text: I love this Italian - it's on one of my favorite streets in London (the very quaint Lamb Conduits Street) and the food is always excellent.I'm not alone though - it's get very busy and even on a weekday they're turning people away. Probably has something to do with the cheap prices in this part of the capital, the staff, the complimentary olives and breadsticks, authentic ingredients and the fact that you can guarantee a great (and pretty lively) meal any night of the week.Try the tiramisu. It's homemade and won't disappoint

MHJLpWTriPD3qrxgelu6Vw.text: Decent italian food and a great price for central London. The homey atmosphere makes this place even better.

vkpn_dWIA83Qifx7vl-EkQ.text: Ciao Bella is a great venue for a dinner with friends, it's always busy and has a great atmosphere but it wouldn't be my first choice for a more intimate evening. However the foods is always good and the house wine's excellent, all for a reasonable price. Service is good but can be a little slow on busy nights, but when having a meal out with friends I don't mind this too much as it gives you a chance to catch up and enjoy more wine!

Q5vUCkzqRf755B7yuxfTRQ.text: I had a successful romantic date here last week. Without prompting or reserving we were given a nice candlelit table in the corner of the downstairs room. We got a neapolitana pizza and gnocchi with salvia, both of which were excellent. The house wine was merely passable, but then, it's house wine innit? At the end, after tiramisu and coffees the bill was pleasantly low. If I was visiting again I would try and nab one of the outside tables, particularly if the weather was in any way nice. The street it's on is a quiet one and it would make for an atmospheric meal to sit out and take in the city.

L7wyITdMo8H6HwO4NAPvfw.text: amazing restaurant!! the only down side is the tables in there are very close together hence not that most comfortable place. However, the food is amazing and reasonably priced for the expensive london city. I had their carbonara which was very rich and amazingly good. My friend ordered their lobster pasta which was awesome as well. We shared a calamari, loved it!! Would definitely go back if I go back to London!

RnZL9Hp9njRAMBryKQ7wJQ.text: we were a party of six on a saturday lunchtime - with some teens wanting pizza and some adults wanting something a bit more sophisticated. With a very drinkable Valpolicella, coffee and soft drinks we all had two courses each for £150. Would go again. Busy but not crowded.

9mMb0e3DLG3VbkQMwZ9z3Q.text: Great Italian restaurant and I can only echo the reviews of others here. We had an early sitting, so unfortunately couldn't take advantage of the piano bar, but I would definitely go back again & settle in for a late night & enjoy the warm atmosphere.

ZHq_FzOWjamNETbe5UUCiw.text: EXCELLENT found this by using Qype before visiting Bloomsbury. The staff were very friendly, attentive and great with my children aged 8 and 12 , the food is simply delicious and reasonably priced, even the wine didn't break the bank. It was so good that even though we were only in London for 3 nights we returned here for second meal that was equally as good as the first. Plates were cleared at both meals and anyone with two children and a wife thats the fussiest eater ever will know this is quite an achievement. If you like Italian you'll love this restraunt.

fQKu-PllxOwCmbHru-Zp2A.text: This restaurant does good, large pizzas and other Italian dishes to the accompaniment of loud and uplifting live piano music. I would recommend sitting outside on summery live music nights if you want to hear your conversation. The music is good and still reaches your ears! Or sit inside for a lively, old fashioned music-and-meal. The food is excellent, atmosphere busy and cheerful. The sort of place you can take family, friends or colleagues to. Good for long pizza lunches too.

B_Fh9bZxwHe9sxbxnHtjEg.text: This Italian restaurant is able to successfully cater to both the wealthy local population and students on a student budget from nearby Goodenough College and LSE. The pizzas are delicious and can be ordered at the table or for take-out. Hors d'oeuvres comprise olives, bread sticks and delicious chunks of parmesan cheese. This reviewer was disappointed to find that refills cost extra, especially as the service can be a bit slow, especially during busy times. The wait is well worth it, though. The pastas are delicious and varied and the ingredients are fresh. Leaving Ciao Bella you feel like you are leaving your own private corner of Italy and re-entering the reality of London streets. This might well be the wine speaking...

ob2aXWEH94uUuc15u9eWBw.text: i actually crave ciao bella all the time! i just think its good value for money and a great place to go when you just want to chill and have a laugh! the service is good and everytime i go the food is amazing, dont think ive ever had a bad meal there!! the atmosphere is really italian based but thats what you want when you go to an italian restaurant!..the owner is always there everday of the week which is a really good sign.. it does get really busy everyday but thats all part of it! it is what it is!
